ygData.subject: Re: Interesting notes on evolving CTRNN substrates with HyperNEAT(fitness zero?)
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, here is an idea:  Remove the arms and head from the humanoid body and from the substrate, and then train the substrate to perform the simpler walking

Peter, here is an idea:  Remove the arms and head from the humanoid 
body a=
nd from the substrate, and then train the substrate to perform 
the simpler=
 walking problem with the simplified biped (using the same 
training regime=
n you did before, but this time with HyperNEAT).  

Then add the body parts=
 and the outputs back onto the *same* 
substrate that has now been trained =
to control a biped.  Although it 
will not work right away, the hope is tha=
t some of the underlying 
relationships leanred with the simpler biped will=
 be extensible to 
the full humanoid.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "p=
etar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> I discussed it with Tyl=
er some months ago, and he actually told me 
> the same, that he evolved it=
 to oscillate its legs first. 
> I took a different path - I rewarded cycli=
c activity in the hips 
and 
> knees as well as distance travelled. Besides=
, I used FS-NEAT and 
only 
> 4 outputs for the legs. Very simple. :)
> Wit=
h this approach, NEAT was able to find NNs that have just about 
5-
> 6 con=
nections, oscillating the 4 outputs and moving the legs. It 
was 
> walking=
 (running forward in fact) and I was very very happy :) 
> My problems star=
ted when I added the head, the arms and the feet. 
> From 4 outputs they be=
came 15. This enlarged the search space a 
lot, 
> and the FS-NEAT approach=
 usually connected.. like your left feet 
> connected to your neck and I wa=
nt you to walk - it doesn't work :) 
> Using a fully connected CTRNN is lik=
e a fixed-genome evolution so I 
> dropped that as well. 
> I decided to us=
e HyperNEAT and give it a substrate that is close to 
> the human's actual =
geometry in space. Left is left, right is right, 
> up and down... 
> The i=
nputs are located in the center and are a 3D vector, 
> representing the he=
ad's current velocity. It's like the.. organ 
found 
> in the middle ear (c=
an't recall how to express that in english :)) 
> The hidden neurons are or=
ganised in a circle around these inputs. 
> The outputs have green color an=
d: the topmost is the neck's joint 
> desired angle. The arms are located b=
elow it in the left and right 
> sides of the substrate. Each arm has 3 out=
puts. The legs are 
> organised in a similar manner, and each leg has 4 out=
puts. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <ksta=
nley@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter,
> > 
> > I believe the challenge in this domai=
n is indeed the fitness 
> function 
> > as opposed to the learning method.=
  The problem is that it is 
very 
> > difficult to describe exactly what s=
hould be rewarded early on.  
> > Rewarding # of steps tends to encourage a=
 single flailing step 
yet 
> > misses better oscillatory behavior.  Even i=
f an individual does 
> learn 
> > a leg-based oscillation, it will likely =
fall and therefore never 
be 
> > noticed.
> > 
> > When Tyler Streeter was=
 working on this problem in his Verve 
> project 
> > (http://www.vrac.iast=
ate.edu/~streeter/verve/gallery.html), which 
> > used NEAT with leaky-inte=
grator neurons, I discussed this problem 
> > with him often.  I believe he=
 ended up finding a clever way to 
> reward 
> > oscillatory behavior.  Tha=
t is the most important thing, since 
it's 
> > really the key to walking: =
it's necessary for the circuit to 
> produce 
> > an oscillating pattern.  =
I may be remembering wrong, but I think 
he 
> > may have started getting i=
t to work by hanging the biped from an 
> > invisible "string" from the cei=
ling, so that it could not fall, 
and 
> > simply training it to oscillate =
its legs.  Have you tried 
> discussing 
> > it with Tyler?
> > 
> > By the=
 way, can you please remind me what the inputs and outputs 
> are 
> > on y=
our substrate?
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_ch=
ervenski" 
> > <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi Ken, 
> > > 
> > >=
 The fitness function used in the binary is Average_Head_Height 
* 
> > > N=
umber_of_FootSteps_Taken. The second multiplier rewards 
> > individuals 
>=
 > > that tend to walk around instead of staying still. I know it is 
> > m=
aybe 
> > > wrong to assign 0.000 fitness, but I usually hope that in early=
 
> > > generations at least some individuals will get a score above 
> zer=
o, 
> > > and therefore survive. Is this a right thing to do or I should 
>=
 > > translate all fitnesses above 0.000 ? Like Total_Fitness +=3D 
> 1.0; =
? 
> > > The Number_of_FootSteps_Taken is actually an integer and it 
makes=
 
> > the 
> > > fitness landscape look like stairs... This is not good, bu=
t I 
> can't 
> > > think of another way to encourage walking around.. Rewa=
rding 
> cyclic 
> > > activity in the output neurons didn't help me much..=
 It is the 
> same 
> > > thing. 
> > > 
> > > I am experimenting with a lo=
t of fitness functions every day. 
The 
> > > best individual I got for the=
 balancing task was actually the 
> same 
> > as 
> > > the one found using=
 regular NEAT - just standing. A way to 
> prevent 
> > > this is may be to=
 choose random initial positions for the 
model.. 
> > Or 
> > > the ground=
 plane can be made moving randomly.. 
> > > Anyway, it seems that the fitne=
ss function is wrong, since this 
> way 
> > > of achieving the goal is too=
 easy for the evolution to find.
> > > 
> > > I am currently trying out how=
 good are they to walk. I replaced 
> the 
> > > Average_Head_Height with T=
otal_Distance_Travelled in the 
fitness 
> > > function. 
> > > 
> > > I be=
lieve that HyperNEAT is able to handle such complex dynamic 
> > > control =
tasks, given the right substrate geometry. Results so 
far 
> > do 
> > > n=
ot show a big progress. But there are a lot of parameters to 
> tweak 
> > =
> and play with. Substrate configurations also. 
> > > 
> > > Ken, what abo=
ut the source code, can you compile it?  
> > > 
> > > Peter
> > > 
> > > -=
